Description:
After donating 150 food bags to food banks across London last year, Universal Music’s UK Staff Charity Committee is back this year with our annual food drive to donate to even more parts of the UK.

We need your support to donate as much as possible to food banks. This year, in addition to collecting food items, we are again raising funds for The Trussell Trust - an amazing charity that supports a network of over 1,200 food bank centres to provide emergency food and compassionate, practical support to people in crisis.

We’d be very grateful for any donation you feel able to give to this fantastic cause.

Please see the below price points on how you can help:

£15 - £15 can supply a single recipient with a week of evening meals

£30 - £30 can provide a single parent family with breakfast and dinner for a week

£40 - £40 can help feed a family of four their meals for a week

£100 - £100 can allow us to provide an average family with food and essentials for a fortnight
Title: Universal Music UK's Staff Charity Committee Food Bank Collection Oct 2021

Description:
In March next year, 3 aging cyclists are going to cycle 100 miles.
We’re going to raise money for the surprisingly large number of foodbanks across the Sussex coast. 

One of these men helps to run a local food bank and the need for food support in the community is now huge. In the 50 mile stretch between Chichester and Seaford there are 30 food banks. 

These foodbanks need support. Three portly men on bikes is not the ideal mechanism for this but its where are.

We are cycling 100 miles. From Worthing to  Chichester to Seaford to Worthing. The 3 of us are going to attempt to raise £30,000 for the 30 foodbanks along the route. 

We will be stopping at many of these foodbanks along the way, to highlight the shocking scale of need. It would be great to see you there cheering us on. In the New year we will up date this page with details of the route: and to feature some of our generous sponsors.

So please give generously if you can. Whatever you can give will make all the difference to the foodbanks and the wonderful work they do.
Title: 100 mile cycle to raise money for 30 food banks

Description:
Annabel and Daniel started running the Mini-Marcothon as a personal challenge. They soon decided they wanted to do something to help others as part of their challenge, and thought this would keep them extra motivated during their runs, especially when it’s dark outside or the weather is bad (well it is December!). So they decided to raise money for the Trussell Trust food banks so that they can help people get food especially during these cold winter months. 

They would be very grateful for any donations to help them raise money for a wonderful charity and make sure everyone  has access to food. 

Thank you.

——————-

Our vision is for a UK without the need for food banks.We say this because it’s not right that anyone cannot afford their own food. That’s why we are working towards a just, compassionate future, where no one should have to use a food bank to get by.Our vision is ambitious, but we know that if we work together it is possible. We can create a future where nobody goes hungry, because nobody will allow it – when we work Together for Change.#TogetherForChange
Title: Annabel & Daniel run Mini-Marcothon - run 1 mile every day in December

Description:
Lockdown Languages was initially created when the schools closed in mid-March and I wondered if I could put my Modern Languages degree in French and Spanish to any use.  I started off by offering to help friends’ kids with their home lessons. 

Since then, Lockdown Languages has taken a few twists and turns and I’m now also doing basic classes for adults and some boozy Zooms with groups who just want to learn a few words and have some fun.  I can manage very basic Italian too!   

There are also collaborative classes with friends whose skills are on a par with mine where we all prepare a short written piece to read and discuss new words and grammar.  

There are no fees.   Frankly, I’m not qualified and extremely rusty.  But if there’s a way of raising a little bit of money through this that would be amazing.  So if you’ve enjoyed a class,  or have no interest in taking part but think the concept is fun, I would be delighted if you could chip in a little bit to support Foodbanks through the Trussell Trust.   Thank you, merci, gracias xx 

Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. It’s not right that people can’t afford the basics. With your help, we can help end the need for food banks.As a nation, we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange
Title: Lockdown Languages in aid of Trussell Trust

Description:
For those who know me, I currently get very little sleep. This means I have come to rely heavily on chocolate and other delicious treats, just to get me through the day (alas, i don't like coffee, otherwise I'd be all over it!). 

My chocolate reliance has gotten a little out of hand and last week I ate so much I got a bit jittery and shaky. Definitely time to do something to combat my greediness and adopt a more healthy diet. And i thought, why not give up chocolate and do something more positive with my personal challenge? Raising money for the local food bank and being less of a greedy guts makes perfect sense to me.

Here's to raising money for those in need and for (hopefully) reducing my risk of an extra chin and flab role and diabetes!
Title: Jamie's Chocolate Challenge

Title: Christmas Cards for Cash

Description:
Over 3 days, colleagues from the LBG North East Regional team will each take part in a half marathon walk in the footsteps of the legend that is Robin Hood. From the heart of Sherwood Forest, to the Coast at Robin Hoods Bay, and ending at Robin Hoods Tree (Hadrian's Wall).

One million meals! It's a staggering figure. And yet the reality is, based on predictions, that it's the amount of meals S6 Foodbank will need to provide over the next year, to people in food emergency in Sheffield. From supporting around 150 people a week from 4 sites a year ago, the team are now supporting 1000 people a week from 9 sites. I believe that nobody in Sheffield should have to face going hungry. That's why I'm fundraising to support the work of S6 Foodbank. Thank you for supporting me - this donation is #ForAllSheffield
Title: On behalf of LBG Team Sheffield & Nottingham - Robin Hood & colleagues

Description:
We’re hosting a virtual live pub quiz to raise money for the Trussel trust. Due to the current situation foodbanks are getting less donations but are in higher demand than usual. We’d like to raise £40 (or more) to try and make a difference, even if it only just helps out one family.

Please donate as much or as little as you want considered your ‘entry’ to to the quiz but you are not obliged to!! Friends and family are also welcome to donate if they’d like to x

Title: Patrick is Living Below the Line

Description:
My son and I both hit big birthdays this year and decided to cycle from John O'Groats to Land's End. We will be doing this from 7th-23rd August, a total projected distance of 984 miles. Due to strong family connections with the Trussell Trust and, rather sadly, a growing need for foodbanks in the UK, we want to try and raise £1,000 to support the Trust's work.

Our vision is for a UK without the need for food banks. We say this because it’s not right that anyone cannot afford their own food. That’s why we are working towards a just, compassionate future, where no one should have to use a food bank to get by. Our vision is ambitious, but we know that if we work together it is possible. We can create a future where nobody goes hungry, because nobody will allow it – when we work Together for Change.#TogetherForChange
Title: Rob's JOGLE - Father/Son John O'Groats to Land's End ride

No parent should have to feel the pain of not being able to feed their children. With this money raised between now and  mid December, the foodbank will be able to buy wholesale quantities of the items needed to provide local families with a Christmas meal.
Title: Liz's Christmas Doorstep Portraits

Description:
This year has seen an 89% increase in need for emergency food parcels, 107% increase in parcels going to children.

The number of families with children receiving food parcels has almost doubled compared to last year. 

Many foodbanks are struggling to meet the demand.

Pay it forward this pay day and donate your lunch money to help the foodbanks. A McDonalds will cost you about £6, for a few pounds more foodbanks can supply a healthy, nutritionally balanced food box that will last an individual 3 days. Let's #dosomethingfornothing NO2. 🥰
Title: Geez yer lunch money.

Description:
Endings and beginnings - letting go of the old year and breathing into the new. 

12 noon - 1pm UK time

This will be an active session using movement, Do-In and self-shiatsu. We will use shiatsu techniques to get connected with our own bodies and feel resourced, using acupressure points and movement. We will connect especially with the Large Intestine and Lung meridians to help us with letting go and breathing in.

2020 has been a year when poverty has become increasingly prevalent in the UK and more people are using foodbanks. This fundraiser will give a little back to the Trussell Trust to support people living in poverty.

Description:

Description:
We are fortunate that the majority of our TalkTalk colleagues are provided with the tools, flexibility and support to be able to work from home during this crisis.

Foodbanks will be supporting many families and individuals through the coming weeks and possibly months. 

This will undoubtedly put a further strain on these services. There is less footfall in supermarkets, resulting in fewer donations at foodbank collection points. Many children rely upon school meals to obtain their primary nourishment. The school closures will result in more people approaching foodbanks for assistance.

If you can support this service by donating what you would normally spend on a days commute or your morning coffee, this will add up and could be the difference between a family eating or going without.

I will be adding a donation on a week by week basis as long as this continues.

If you are able to donate, please don't forget to add gift aid!

Thank you.

Title: Eat out to Help Out - Pay it Forward

Description:
I believe that MPs are elected to speak for the people, but our MPs do not seem to be listening. Poverty can affect anyone, and in a time of national crisis such as this pandemic it is affecting more and more families.

Last year, food banks in The Trussell network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. This was before Covid-19.

MPs are paid £80k per year, it has been reported they are to receive a £3k payrise, they claim expenses and on top of this they can earn money through consultancy work and other jobs - but the people they are paid to represent are struggling.

The premise of this campaign is simple:

  • Donate just £2 to The Trussell Trust to support their national food bank network and provide food to those in need.
  • By donating you are sending a message to our MPs that they do not speak for me, every donation is your voice to make them listen.
  • If you feel able to donate more, it is up to you.

It’s not right that people can’t afford the basics. With your help, we can support food banks, and as a nation, tell our MPs that we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

https://www.trusselltrust.org/

https://www.parliament.uk/about/mps-and-lords/members/pay-mps/

https://fullfact.org/economy/poverty-uk-guide-facts-and-figures/

https://www.endchildpoverty.org.uk/
Title: They do not speak for me

Description:
The Brick's aim is to eradicate homelessness and poverty in our community. They support homeless people, those facing homelessness, and people experiencing crisis or poverty in the Wigan borough. People who are marginalised by society, who can, with support, become independent and contribute positively to their communities. Services include crisis intervention, housing and health support on behalf of the Council, a foodbank, social and employment training, and wide-ranging volunteering opportunities. They ensure no one in our community gets left behind.

From now until the 14th of December Lowri Beck is collection foodbank donations on behalf of The Brick.

Title: Lynda's Life

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Short version: £25 from 100 people, helps 100 families in their time of need. Just donating what you can AND also sharing this page can make a huge difference. I'll be living on £1/day for 6 days at the end of July.

Live Below The Line

Live below the line is a challenge from The Hunger Project. It is quite simply - live below the line for a given time period. Sometimes a day, sometimes 5.

The aim is to raise awareness of extreme poverty abroad, nationally and at home, and to raise funds.

The line is the world extreme poverty line, below which 1.2 billion people live. That's a mind boggling number. The line is £1 a day. £1 a day for food - all your food for one day.

Bringing closer to home: 13 million people live in poverty in the UK. 600,000 of those live in Greater Manchester - 1 in 4 people. 3.9 million children in the UK live in poverty. 91,000 of those are children - the majority have 1 or more parents in work.

These are the people that access foodbanks - over 1 million times in the past year. 1 million times when someone would go hungry instead.

They do this week in, week out, unrelentingly.

6 pounds, 6 days

As a result, I will live below the line for 6 days. That's the 5 days people normally do, with a day on top. I'll be doing this from Sunday 23rd July 2017 to Friday 28th July 2017.

Why Manchester Food Bank

It's on our doorstep. It's personal. 1 in 4 people in manchester are in poverty. No-one chooses poverty - poverty chooses them. Manchester Food Bank was seeded by the Trussel Trust, and supported by them as part of their national collective of foodbanks. 

Why am I doing this?

I'm doing this because I think modern society should be able to exist without people living on the borders of starvation. Many years ago I had to live on a similar budget to this, but I think things have become worse. I was lucky enough to be able to use education to lift myself out of that. Many people are not lucky enough to do that. In the absence of change, they need assistance.

I feel strongly that foodbanks should not need to exist, and that they are a failure of society. Until they're no longer needed, those using foodbanks need help.

Lastly, it's in essence to raise awareness and to try and do something positive that I couldn't do myself.

Why such a high target?

Because it matters. I've picked a figure that is achievable and would make a difference. Yes, it's a hard target, but if I get 1/2 way there I will have succeeded. Every level of support helps. Some baseline numbers: £10 buys a basket of food for an emergency food parcel, £25 buys a family 3 days of food. (£2/day is not luxury), £50 restocks supplies on the things the food back runs short of for 1 week

Which ever way you look at it, the target makes a difference.

  • Helps 100 families over a difficult period. Just 100 families. On average 400 people.?
  • Or it helps 250 people in a period of emergency
  • Or it helps the foodbank for a whole year to not worry about things they run short of.

No matter the actual amount raised though, it makes a difference.

Bear in mind:

  • How much do you spend on entertainment a week / a month? Can you go without that once?
  • Rather than a take away, can you cook at home instead?
  • If you're contemplating a new gadget, can you wait a month and instead donate 1/12th the cost?
  • As little as £1 helps, that seems like a little, but it can /literally/ be a day's food for someone.

You might not be in a position to help financially. I get that.

  • If you can't give, please share this page, this helps. Each time you share this page, you increase the chances of another £10 towards the goal.
  • Failing that, please add foods to a collection point. It goes directly to helping the same foodbanks.

Gift Aid

Please, PLEASE, please gift aid your donation if you can. It boosts the intake. it means that every £20 donated raises £25 for the charity - with the extra £5 coming from taxes you already pay - forcing the govt to do a tiny fraction of their part too.

Donate via text

You can also donate via mobile phone. Examples:
  • If you want to donate 5 days' food - £10 - you do this by texting "MCFB75 £10" to 70070
  • If you want to donate a day's food - £2 - you do this by texting "MCFB75 £2" to 70070

Practicalities

I'll track my progress here: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/sparkslabs . I'll provide proof of costs here as well. The key practicality is that you can only eat foods you buy that week.

One common/small exception I've noticed is people allow themselves salt and pepper. (Since you buy those very very rarely, and use fractions of a penny if that if anything) But no spices, *nothing* else you might take for granted.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Title: Lewis Silkin's Christmas Kindness

Description:
The Coronavirus is already having a hugely negative economic and social impact across the UK, whether that’s job uncertainty or self-isolation preventing many vulnerable people from buying the basic items they need.

As an education provider Bournemouth & Poole College wants to engage with our community to help raise awareness and funds to help people through these trying times.

We are working hard to ensure we have a real, positive impact on the lives of our local communities. We have the resources and the fantastic staff to help make it happen.

That is why we are joining FE colleges nationally in the FE Food Bank Friday initiative. Since the programme started on Friday 20 March many colleges across the country are pledging to take part.

As staff and students are now working and studying remotely, it is becoming difficult for staff and students to physically donate any items. That is why we have joined this fundraising campaign, which aims to raise £2,000 so that foodbanks can continue to operate despite social distancing taking place across the country.

Title: Birthday fundraising for The Trussell Trust

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

When I came across the work that Little Village do I was stunned. It’s like a foodbank, but instead of food, it offers essential items like clothing, books, toys and baby equipment to parents in need, right across London. It’s frankly alarming that thousands of families need to rely on ‘hand me downs’ and the good will of other people to barely survive. This is just for essential items. I am saddened that in this day and age tiny babies and children under 5 are going without the most basic of items right here in London, items I completely took for granted when I was pregnant and during the early years of my children growing up. 

Can you imagine trying to breastfeed your little one without any breast pads to pop in after? Or not having enough nappies? Imagine not being able to clothe your children appropriately. Imagine trying to entertain your smallest children without the most basic of toys or books? 

This is where I think I can make a small difference. As part of my ongoing #asyouaremotherhood campaign across Instagram and Facebook, I'm celebrating and highlighting those of us (silent) women heroes, who everyday, do all we can to provide for our children and to be the best mothers we can be.

There is such a pressure for us mums to be perfect: we all strive for perfection everyday when the reality is, perfection doesn't exist.

We all worry, are anxious about whether we're doing the right thing for our unborn baby or the children we already have. We can look at others and think they're somehow doing it better than us, and feel like we've failed.

We must change our attitudes and change the way we treat ourselves.

That's why I'm giving away a limited number of mother and baby photoshoots to celebrate how amazing and unique we are as mothers, how we ARE doing all we can to help our children. 

And that our best is good enough. We are good enough.

Through this project, I can ask pregnant women and mums to come into my studio, get a fabulous photoshoot to show how fabulous they are (just as they are without the need for fancy or OTT props) - and spread the word about self-love and acceptance. 

And then in return all I'd ask is a contribution to Little Village.

This is my way to give back to some struggling families on my own doorstep? Little Village does just that; giving the gift of the most basic but essential things to babies and children who really need them. 

As their website says: “It takes a village to raise a child - this is especially true in London where we often feel alone as parents.

“Little Village is a gift from one family to another, passed on with love.”

If I ask each of my photography clients to donate, say, just £20 to this cause, I would forgo my booking fee of usually £95. Clients could of course donate more if they wish or were able to, but I thought this would be an excellent start. 

So if you're keen to book a Maternity or Baby photoshoot with me, I’ll direct you to this page where you can donate what you can and then we’ll see what happens. Things will snowball from there. Let’s do this together and be part of something hopeful to change the world we live in, right on our doorsteps.

Title: Alistair Logan's Lockdown Haircut

Description:
Last year I was unfortunately diagnosed with cancer. Whilst receiving Chemotherapy, I was feeling sorry for myself and was bored with feeling tired and yukky all the time. It was then I came up with an idea.

I decided to have a get better list. NOT a bucket list because a bucket list is things to do before you die, but I am planning to be around for a long time yet. Anyway, for every chemo treatment I have added an activity. They are all quite crazy things such as indoor sky diving; trampoline Parks; Go Ape etc. You get the sort of idea

The next event is taking place on Saturday the 9th June. My daughter has bought the family and I a very strange experience. We are going to be flung off the Killiecrankie bridge on a Bungee Swing. I told her that I was no longer scared of anything but really?!?

Well here is where you come in. I thought while doing this it may be a good idea to raise money for a good cause. I am hoping to raise money for The Storehouse Foodbank, which is run by the Falkirk VIneyard Church. This is a very important charity and very close to my heart. It seeks to help disadvantaged families in our local areas by providing them with food and other essentials in a time of crisis. If you feel you could contribute anything then I wold be really grateful and it may give the extra incentive to fly off the bridge.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and thank you for your generosity.

With lots of love

Michelle

Title: Halfords Colleague Christmas Raffle

Description:
As we all prepare to celebrate the festive season as best we can during the coronavirus pandemic, it's more important than ever to remember those who have been affected by job loss, illness, bereavement and the many other issues facing people during this difficult year. The Trussell Trust aims to end the need for food banks and at this time needs all the help it can get. 100,000 people needed foodbanks for the first time at the start of the pandemic and this Christmas, 670,000 more people will fall into destitution and become unable to afford the essentials of life, let alone the luxuries we all enjoy at Christmas.

Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. It’s not right that people can’t afford the basics. With your help, we can help end the need for food banks.As a nation, we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

Walking in the beautiful Hampshire countryside is something I enjoy doing most days, so I wanted to set myself the goal of walking a total of 100 miles between the start of the second lockdown (November 5th) and December 31st with the aim of raising £1, 000 for the Trussell Trust. I would be enormously grateful for any donation you are able to make. Thank you so much!
Title: Angela's 100 mile Walk

Title: Matthew's London Marathon page

Description: The last few months have seen immense suffering and hardship from storms and flooding. However the outbreak of the Coronavirus has quite literally changed everyones lives and turned society upside down.However, The Salvation Army is resolute and strong and just as we did in the Spanish Flu pandemic, and during the bombing and the Blitz we will carry on, doing what we can to support people and communities in the ways that we can, within the Government guidelines.In true Salvation Army Spirit, our greatest strength is our flexible, responsive local presence. Right now, each of our 650 corps and community centres will know exactly what the most effective things are to do. We are not just responding to the virus impact in one or two ways, but dozens and dozens of different ways, from food banks to counselling, from supporting NHS isolation units to checking up on people who are living alone. In Carnforth we have chosen to work alongside existing support networks to support and protect our Community. Please give what you can to enable us to help as many people as possible!
Title: Carnforth Corps & Community 's Carnforth COVID Response

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.  I work for Teenage Cancer Trust and joined the South London Scrubbers as a volunteer in April to sew PPE scrub caps, masks, aprons, laundry bags and ear savers for the local NHS, care homes and foodbanks. This volunteer group has sewn over 3000 sets of scrubs plus thousands of other PPE items, and my fellow students from my adult education sewing class have also joined the project and are sewing away to help support all our carers during this time.

While sewing I am also trying to raise money for the charity I work for Teenage Cancer Trust that supports 13-24 year olds with cancer. We fund specialist age appropriate units, nurses and youth support coordinates nationally as well as running a range of support programs for young people with cancer. Please show your support for my sewing by making a donation and dont forget to gift aid your donation if you can.

Description:
Prince's Trust Team Programme (Team 53) at Glasgow Clyde College - Langside Campus are raising money for Glasgow South East Food bank.

Glasgow SE Food bank don't think anyone in our community should have to face going hungry. That's why we are trying to raise funds to help them provide three days nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to them in crisis. They are part of a nationwide network of food banks, supported by the Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK.

We are taking donations and food donations to help this worthy cause within our community.

We appreciate any help that you could provide us either financially to help us meet our donation target or by donating food to our food bank collection happening at Glasgow Clyde College - Langside Campus on Monday 12th March - Friday 16th March 2018.

At food bank drop off points we are looking for items such as:

UHT Milk
Tinned Fruit
Tinned Vegetables
Chocolate
Sugar
Squash/Fruit Juice
Tinned Tomatoes
Rice Pudding/Custard
Soup

(Please ensure all food is in date prior to donation).

Thank you for your support

Description:
In 2018 I ran three marathons in three months, this year I will go one race further and I am running four races in three months. 

I will be following a special space aged scientifically formulated couch to marathon 5 month training plan which entails pounding around Middleton, Heywood or Rochdale until I am absolutely knackered. This will also be supplemented with a tri-weekly Olympic style rigorous aquatic regime of keep on swimming until my arms and legs give up. If you see an extremely tired, overweight mess who is struggling badly in a yellow jacket in these areas, it's most probably me. As usual, extremely poor efforts of a physical training masterclass will be reported back to my Diary Of A Rotund Forrest Gump Facebook page HERE >

https://www.facebook.com/FourMarathonFurlong/

On a more serious note, both foodbanks work extremely hard for those that have fallen on hard times and help those that need support the most. They are a credit to our community. Please give if you can to these two very worthy causes.

Due to Covid the original marathons have been cancelled so the first run is now to be at Heaton Park in October. The second race is at Tatton Park in November.


Money to be collected by Inspire and split between Heywood and Middleton Foodbanks.

Thank you for reading my page.
Title: Four Races in 3 Months

Description:

As we are unable to hold our normal Harvest festival service this year we are holding a Scarecrow Harvest Festival!     We are raising much needed funds for the Harrogate District Foodbank who provide emergency food and support to local people in crisis.  

Please support this event in any way that you can by either creating your own scarecrow to display outside your home, or go on the Scarecrow hunt and vote for your favourite.    

Please donate what you can to help our local community who would go hungry without the help from this fantastic, hard-working foodbank.   

For more details on the Scarecrow Harvest Festival please go to www.strobertschurch.co.uk/wordpress/?page_id=8639 or our Facebook page St Robert's Church, Pannal.

The St Robert's Scarecrow team.

Title: Stacey's Donate Your Dinner

Description:
In the
UK, more than 14 million people are living in poverty – including 4.5 million
children. We support more than 1,200 food bank centres in the UK to provide a
minimum of three days’ nutritionally-balanced emergency food to people who have
been referred in crisis, as well as support to help people resolve the crises
they face. Between April 2018 and March 2019, food banks in our network
provided a record 1.6 million food supplies to people in crisis, a 19%
increase on the previous year.

At the moment people have enough to lose
sleep over without worrying where their next meal is coming from and how they
are going to feed their families.  As you
have probably seen on the news, some NHS staff are having to rely on foodbanks,
this in itself shouldn’t be happening but that’s a discussion for another day.

By donating you will be supporting the
UK’s most vulnerable people and some of the incredible staff in our NHS during
this pandemic and lord knows we need to be pulling together now more than ever.  Please give as much or as little as you can
to this wondrous charity.
Title: Rocksteady's Funny Hat Fundraiser

Description: We have decided to run at least 50km before our 9th birthdays in March in aid of The Trussell Trust which supports food banks across the UK. We are doing this because a few weeks ago we went to donate to our local foodbank and the lady there told us that some people in our neighbourhood had to choose between eating or staying warm, which we don't think is a choice you should to have to make. We have also been inspired by Marcus Rashford's campaign to help hungry families. We have run before but 50km is a really big challenge for us and we are determined to reach our target. Please consider sponsoring our running for this very important cause. Thank you!

Description: The Stepping Out for S6 campaign is a challenge to individuals to complete 60k steps in a given time to raise money for S6 Foodbank. Every donation made goes directly to support their work. Without the assistance of people and businesses in Sheffield, S6 Foodbank wouldnt be able to continue to support their guests, launch new sites and tackle the ongoing food crisis in Sheffield which is being exacerbated by coronavirus.S6 Foodbank are expecting the increased need to continue for the foreseeable future, as more people experience difficulty as a result of coronavirus and its wider consequences. I believe that nobody in Sheffield should have to face going hungry. A donation of £27 provides food and basic essentials for a family of three for three days. I am aiming to raise at least £40 to help S6 Foodbank reach their £40,000 target. Whatever I raise (up to that target) will be match-funded by the Government via the Love Your Neighbour partnership, meaning S6 Foodbank receives double the amount.Thank you for sponsoring me, and a huge thank you too from Chris and the team

Title: 24 Hour Gaming Marathon

Description:
If the pandemic has taught me anything, it’s that truly anyone can fall on hard times. More people than ever are turning to foodbanks for support. 

Some of us might be wishing through all this that we could jet off on holiday, but others are just wishing they could get back to making ends meet. 

With that in mind, I’m taking on a tower climb in the popular holiday city of Dubai! No long haul flights though, this challenge is virtual!

I’m climbing the Burj Khalifa – 2909 stairs – 160 floors over the month of February to raise money for FareShare.

I’ll track my floors climbed each day on my Fitbit and keep you guys updated! By the end of February, I’ll have reached the top and I'll be (virtually) knackered!

Description:
Our vision is for a UK without the need for food banks.

We say this because it’s not right that anyone cannot afford their own food. That’s why we are working towards a just, compassionate future, where no one should have to use a food bank to get by.

Our vision is ambitious, but we know that if we work together it is possible. We can create a future where nobody goes hungry, because nobody will allow it – when we work Together for Change.

#TogetherForChange

Title: Carol Singing with Bobby

Description:
In lieu of gifts we would appreciate a donation to the Trussel Trust,.

More and more people are being forced to use food banks because they cannot afford the basics in life. Last year, food banks in the Trussell Trusts network provided 1.6 million three-day emergency food parcels to people in crisis, with over 500,000 of these going to children. This was an increase of almost 20% on the previous year.Now, as the Coronavirus pandemic develops, its likely that increasing numbers of people will need support from their local food bank. As food bank staff and volunteers work to source and distribute food to people who need support, their resources are becoming increasingly stretched as they come under additional pressure.We’re  working closely with our network of over 1,200 food banks to work out how we can best support each food bank in the coming months to make sure that they’re able to continue to help people in crisis in their local communities.

Title: Ranuary 2022

Description:
Through my work (as Community & Business Liaison Co-ordinator) I have seen the difference that Stoke-on-Trent Foodbank makes to local people’s lives and want to, in my own time, raise money to help continue this work for the challenging times ahead with the ongoing economic and social affects of Covid-19 not disappearing soon.

I wanted to take up this challenge to make a difference to my life and that of other people.

I have been working mainly from home with 30 minute walks most days, but to build on this, I’ve challenged myself to 10,000 steps a day (almost tripling my current daily exercise!).

With stark annual foodbank usage figures reported in April, I wanted to start on my fundraising challenge as soon as possible in May. I am writing this 6 days in, and am looking at the incentive TO KEEP GOING THROUGHOUT MAY… so far I have been out completing my daily steps in two 40 minute sessions, or once this week as a 30 x 250m length swim with a 5,000 step walk that day. I’ve been out rain and shine, squeezing this into my daily schedule, please would you consider giving TO ENCOURAGE ME TO KEEP GOING!

Also, whatever you give will be used to support people experiencing food crisis in Stoke-on-Trent, referred by professionals to SoT Foodbank, given food thanks to the generous donations of local people and welcomed by our amazing volunteers at our 16 centres, and then signposted to where they can get help with the problem that
brought them to us, to MAKE A LONG TERM DIFFERENCE.

Please GIVE to Walk With Us, working towards a #HungerFreeFuture

THANK YOU for your time and interest.
Title: Caroline's Walk With Us Challenge page

Description:
Last year I ran the big food trolley fundraiser in PureGym Shawlands and all our lovely members managed to fill it 4 times!!! However this year with the gyms being shut due to tier 4 restrictions, this won’t be possible.

I love taking classes, and if you come to them you will know that I dance about like a dafty and put a lot of effort into choreographing them to give you the most enjoyment.

For the 3 weeks throughout lockdown 2.0 in Glasgow I will be running 5 classes every week with a suggested donation to help raise funds for the Glasgow Southwest food bank. 

This year more than ever, families have been hit so hard. Losing jobs and loved ones, Christmas will not be easy. If we can help take one stress away by giving a donation of food, that can ease some pressure for those that need it the most.

For more information on the classes, timetable and suggested donations, please see my Instagram page @kaytee_lifts


Thank you <3

Description:

Here at CooperBurnett LLP, we are excited to be supporting the very first Walk Tonbridge Festival and, as a team, looking forward to taking part in the challenging walking marathon on Sunday 19 September.  The 26-mile course will include segments from eight of the established Walk Tonbridge walks as well as a number of local pubs as check points. It begins at Tonbridge Baptist Church and finishes at Tonbridge Castle. 

We're raising money for Sustain, the community food bank for Tonbridge, run by Tonbridge Baptist Church which provides emergency food supplies to local people experiencing a short-term need. All the food items are donated by individuals or local groups and distributed to recipients referred by front line care agencies.

Description:
In these horrible times we are in and have ahead of us, I love hearing about all the charity work people are doing and I feel like I want to do my bit for something that I think is getting overlooked in these times. Admittedly i'm not going to be running a marathon or swimming the channel or even walking a 100 laps around my flat I just want to do something silly and raise a little bit of money for someone, all i'm going to be doing is dying my hair my fiances favourite colour of purple. If this dying malarkey fails (because shes doing it lol) i will be having to say good bye to my hair period that i've been trying to grow back for nearly a year now!!!!!!!! i know and understand my target isn't to the colonels level but every little helps but for every extra £50 i am agreeing to keep my hair purple/shaved for every month after lockdown aswell. so for example if i raise £100 i have to keep my hair purple/shaved until we have been out of lockdown for a month, £150 would be 2 months so on and so forth.

Description:
The Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (UCKG) is a Christian Ministry and registered charity (1043985) dedicated to helping people live life to the fullest — physically, emotionally and spiritually.

Over the years, we have reached such a diverse group of people that our work has touched millions across over 170 countries. Their unique stories remind us that with the right kind of help and support, the most heartbreaking stories can become tomorrow’s inspirational ones. In these testing times, we are determined to do more. Support us

Title: liam's Coach Revenge

Description:
I started Fitness4All in October 2020 - right in the middle of a global pandemic! As a company we offer a range of non-judgmental fitness classes around the Basingstoke area for all ages and abilities. 
 
Fitness4All is holding a charity Fit-A-Thon on the 8th January 2022, at the Popley Fields Community Centre, starting at 9:10am till 4:15pm, it is just £10 a ticket for the whole day.There will be a a range of different fitness classes available throughout the day, talks about health & fitness and we even have a masseuse there for a small additional cost! ALL donations are going to The Basingstoke Food Bank. 

Everyone is welcome to attend the day, part of the day or just sending a donation will be much appreciated. Please leave a comment if you are attending with your FULL name so we can add you to the list. 

Thank you for the support!!

Description:
Hellooooo and thank you for visiting my JustGiving page! 

On 10th April 2022, I'll be running the Brighton marathon (that I entered in April 2019) and was postponed due to lockdown.  You would have thought I would have spent the following two years training to get faster, but with restrictions on exercising and meeting up with others to train, races cancelled, and a running injury, I took up resistance training instead (Davo said "are you going for a run?" and I said "no" a lot).

However, with my foot injury a lot better (it's now a foot niggle), I've started marathon training - I'm hoping it will help in the long run. 

I'll be raising money for Luton foodbank, which supports families in crisis in Luton, where I teach. 

 Please, if you can, sponsor me the cost of a pint (or 2) - 26.2 miles is a long way by foot and thirsty work!

Description:
Following the success of my recent Big Stitch of Van Gogh's The Starry Night, raising over £2000 for Hull Foodbank, I'll be doing it all again next year!

Between 1 January and 31 December 2022, I'll be cross stitching Alphonse Mucha's The Four Seasons, once again to raise money for Hull Foodbank.

At nearly 120,000 stitches, it's another big piece, which will measure ca. 33 x 18 inches (84 x 45 cm) and will take me over 1000 hours to complete.

As part of this Big Stitch, I'm also hoping to build in one 24-hour stint of stitching and to do some stitching in public places.

I have chosen to fundraise for Hull Foodbank again because, although I really wish foodbanks weren't needed, I fear they're unlikely to become surplus to requirements any time soon.

Once I've completed the piece, I will frame it and sell it to the highest bidder, and the proceeds will be added to the total. More info about how you can make a bid nearer the time.

I'll be posting regular updates of my progress on twitter @mirandamvr and on my FB page 'The Big Four Seasons Stitch'.

Thank you for reading, and I hope you're able to sponsor me :)

Title: Transmit's Christmas Hamper Appeal

Description:
We are passionate St.Mirren supporters who run the Black & White Army supporters website and twitter page (@bawarmy).

On Dec 2nd we launched what we thought would be a bit of community minded festive fun ahead of a huge run of pre-Christmas fixtures for our team.

With Christmas on the way we are even more mindful of those in our local community who are struggling and following up on the amazingly successful Foodbank collections we've seen at the stadium in recent times we thought we'd join in and try and raise some funds for the Renfrewshire Foodbank.

Our challenge to the team was simple. For every point gained in the four fixtures leading up to Christmas the B&W Army site would donate £25 to the foodbank.That meant a glorious 12 point haul against Motherwell, Hamilton, Livingston and St.Johnstone would lead to a whopping £300 donation.

So then we started getting messages from other fans who wanted to join in, and it started to grow and grow and grow and we had pledges coming in from all over the place. That list of heroes who pledged is shown on our own site here at this link;

https://www.blackandwhitearmy.com/12pointsofchristmas

An incredible £2648 per point, pledged by almost 500 supporters!!!

The plan was, and still is, to tally up our points haul after the four matches and to contact all our pledgers on 22nd December to ask for their final donation.

We have however decided to open up the page now for a number of reasons;

1) Some supporters just want to make a one-off contribution
2) Plenty fans want to donate regardless of the results.We can't lie. There is always a risk that we lose all the games :-(
3) Fans can donate as they go, rather than all in one lump at the end
4) We appreciate the Foodbank may be especially stretched at this time of year.
5) We completely appreciate that everyones finances get hammered at this time of year!

So here we are, the page is open. We obviously don't know what our target is going to be as it will be dependent on the points we gain, but we're starting off with a 1 point target of £2648.

We will adjust and update the page as the matches are played.

Thanks to each and every person who has pledged and who has supported and shared this. Other football fans have also joined in which has been massively appreciated, and some of them aren't even from Renfrewshire which is even more amazing!
Title: B&W Army #12PointsOfChristmas

Title: Australian Bushfire Appeal

Description:
63 Air Assault Support Squadron RLC will be commemorating the 75th anniversary of VE Day by collectively completing a 75-hour triathlon.

75 soldiers and officers from the squadron will volunteer for one-hour slots to have all three disciplines in motion over 75 hours. There are 225 slots in total! The challenge will begin at 08:00hrs on Tuesday 5th May and conclude at 11:00hrs on Friday 8th May - just in time for the two-minute silence that the Nation will be observing to commemorate VE Day 75.

Why are we doing this? Due to the current pandemic, the nation has had very little cause for celebration recently. We want to do our upmost to commemorate this momentous day in history which saw WW2 come to an end in Europe.

In true British spirit we will also be rallying together to support two great charities: Colchester Foodbank and the Airborne Museum at Hartenstein.   

Colchester Foodbank supports people in poverty and in crisis. They provide nutritionally balanced emergency food and welfare support to local people who are referred to them. They are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. The foodbank is run by local people for local people, and they rely on the community’s support to provide much-needed help to people in crisis.  Our contributions will help them maintain essential stocks of key products, as well as running sustainable local projects.

The Airborne Museum at Hartenstein in Oosterbeek, Netherlands, commemorates the most famous parachute operation in the history of Airborne Forces – the Battle of Arnhem. The museum not only tells the story of the battle, but it is also a centre for international remembrance. They have come into financial difficulty after their grand-reopening was cancelled by the COVID-19 lockdown. The museum is dependent on funding from visitors and their continued operation has been jeopardised by the global pandemic. 

Any sharing, support, or donations, however small, will be hugely appreciated by all of us at 63 Squadron and our chosen charities.

No more than 3 people at any one time will be exercising and all will be compliant with the Government’s guidance on social distancing. Please stay at home, save lives, and protect the NHS!

Thank you for supporting our challenge!
Title: VE Day 75 Triathlon

My aim for the BIG DAY is to identify 100 different species of birds on my patch - that is, on foot from my home in Wivenhoe, on 27th April.

I'll follow up this event with a bird finding series. You pay me an amount to find you a bird you've always wanted to see and enjoy. Really elusive or exotic birds will require a premium!

I'll reserve the 28th as a back-up day in case the weather is foul on 27th.

Thanks for reading this far and for considering helping Colchester Food Bank. If you want the money to be specifically reserved for Wivenhoe, say so on your message, but Colchester supports us with its warehousing and management, so it all helps!

Glyn’s Wivenhoe Bird Race
At precisely 4.30am I was aware of light filtering through the bedroom curtains...
Aaaagh – I’d missed my alarm! Fortunately, my accomplice for the day, Nick Green, had not and was making tea for a quick vigil on the back patio before we set out on the long tramp around Wivenhoe.
Although I had done some scouting for key breeding birds on territory, the cold, windy conditions would make it something of a lottery on the day – especially at dawn – as to whether the birds would betray their presence with any song.
The Tawny Owls we might have hoped to hear from the back patio drew a blank. The wind was such that we could not hear anything from the estuary as we sometimes can, so we set off at 04.55 for Ferry Marsh. High tide, for what it was worth (it wasn’t going to be e big one) was at around 07.30, so we simply walked around ferry marsh on the sea wall (it is still impassable due to flooding) without lingering. We picked up Sedge, Reed and Cettis warbler without any effort, plus Common & Lesser Whitethroat in the dawn chorus. No Chiffchaffs were heard until we walked back through the woods after looping through them from Lower Lodge after the return journey from opposite the Hythe on the trail. Along the river, we predictably scored Greenshank, Nightingale (2 territorial males either side of the river at Hythe), Common Tern and the more common waders, but no Spotted Redshank or Ruff as we might have hoped. A male Sparrowhawk swooped past us near the Uni and Bullfinches were barely audible above the breeze at the level crossing. The otherwise time-saving scope from Lower Lodge to the lagoons was passed up, but at great distance it would have been nigh impossible to see the Green Sandpipers and other smaller waders from that distance. We had seen 3 Avocets on the estuary the previous day, so felt confident that we would connect more easily than a long-range scan. With just over 2 hours to walk to the Hythe and then Wivenhoe Woods en route to Alresford Creek for high tide, we moved quite quickly. No Nightingales were in song in Wivenhoe wood. In fact, very few birds were evident. There were a couple of Jays to keep the total ticking over but by now, the lack of bird song was slightly concerning. A Cuckoo did at least make itself heard from across the river.
Back on the trail after Wivenhoe Woods, we connected with House Martins around West Quay. The walk to the creek yielded only Whimbrel and Bar-tailed Godwit, so we arrived at the metal bench with 40 minutes to scan across to Geedon Marsh before our breakfast rendezvous with Mark Norrington. A brief stop at the barrier did not yield Grey Wagtail, as hoped.
The vigil and the walk along to the bottom of Ford Lane for bacon rolls and coffee, courtesy of Mark, moved the species total from 62 to 71. We darted back to the creek mouth watch point as the wader and wildfowl count to that point was paltry... It seemed evident that most, if not all the usual wintering wildfowl and waders had cleared out, such that, other than the plentiful Whimbrels, we did not add anywhere near the numbers at Alresford that we had hoped, with Golden, Grey and Ringed Plover, Knot, Avocet, Spotted Redshank and Common Sandpiper all absent, as well as Wigeon, Teal and Brent Goose – all of which we would have expected.
We felt that we were 15 species short of where we needed to be when we dragged ourselves away from the creek with 79 species to our name, with one Mediterranean Gull making itself heard above the breeze. At least Little Owl provided an easy hit at Plumptons farm; Buzzards and Marsh Harriers were showing regularly without any thermals to speak of, but there were no more exotic raptors or larger migrants to add. We would have another chance with a later (not very) high tide late in the day, but at this stage, a total of 100 looked very distant, if not impossible without a significant fall of passage migrants. The walk along Cutthroat Lane to Sunnymead & Cockaynes was very quiet. Our remaining hopes of Treecreeper and Coal Tit would be at Cockaynes or Villa wood.
To our abject dismay, there was no Willow Warbler or Garden Warbler in song at Cockaynes. As the clock neared 1pm, I called Debbie to suggest she stays at home rather than deliver our lunch. Discretion became the better part and we managed to trek across Ballast Quay track to aarive back at home for an extended lunch break and a discussion on how we were even going to get over 90, let alone 100.
The biggest gaps in the list of hopefuls (if no longer probables) were of estuarine species, notable by their absence in the first tidal phase. Other incidental passerine species and their likely sites were well spread across the area. The other issue was that Nick had only just recovered from illness and we had already walked 12 miles on just a few hours sleep...
By the time we had eaten as many turkey sandwiches as we could, Nick had retired for a “lie down”. I thought that this would be effectively the end of his participation so togged up again and decided to head out to the creek, via the trail, to see if I could mop up some migrants and to get much luckier with estuarine species. Realistically, this was highly unlikely, but in the context of achieving the highest possible total, this was the obvious option.
To my amazement, as I neared the jetty, Nick called to say that he had woken after barely 30 minutes! We agreed to meet at the creek. By then, I had caught up with the pair of Grey Wagtails on the barrier having heard the male gently singing there from the jetty. The two birds showed briefly before I marched determinedly toward Nick.
Whilst there was nothing new on Barrier Marsh, I was tempted to stop briefly for a Nightingale that was very close to the path in an elevated position. I managed to zoom through a small opening to pick out the bird with the camera and stole quite a pleasing shot.
By the time I reached Nick at the bench, all threats of rain had gone and we enjoyed the next 90 minutes in mostly bright sunshine, doing our best to identify silhouetted images between us and Geedon saltings.
In this time, Nick did brilliantly to pick out a lone Brent Goose and I was able to lock on to a Great White Egret over the saltings. This put us on 82 for the day, but it was now obvious that the estuarine species had all but moved on. A flock of Dunlins were still in the creek, some of which were in almost full summer plumage, as were the Turnstones and 2 of the half dozen or so Bar-tailed Godwits to raise the spirits a little.
Had we stayed out for the rest of the day until dark, we might have added 2 or 3 more species, but there was no way we were going to get near 100, so we called it a day and declared our innings total at 82 species with 17 miles walked.
At the time of writing, we have raised £320 plus GiftAid. I will be doing other activities in a bid to raise this, including a bird finding schedule and making greeting cards with wildlife photos to benefit the Food Bank.
Title: Glyn's Wivenhoe Bird Race

Description:
On Friday 25th June, as a team, we completed our challenge, several days ahead of schedule and managed to go over our target.

Thank you to all who donated to a really worthy cause.  Watch this space for our next quarterly challenge 

Our charities of the year for 2021 are the Rutland Food Bank, Trussell Trust and the Market Harborough Jubilee Food Bank.


The Henry Spain team (8 of us) are going to walk, run or cycle the 837 mile distance from Land's End to John O'Groats over 3 months from 1st April.  We will also be undertaking other various challenges over the year to raise funds.


Kindness and compassion is getting us through this pandemic together. Ending hunger and poverty in the UK is an audacious goal, and as our neighbours are in need, Tom Spain, our Director, has promised to match the funds we raise to go to the Market Harborough Jubilee Food Bank.  We are a mixed bag of athletes, your donation will help to support our cause and will be greatly appreciated.
Title: Henry Spain's Lands End to John O Groats

Hackney Foodbank is part of the Trussell Trust network and runs as an independent charity that has been providing three days emergency food and support to local people in Hackney since 2011.

We would like to beat that this year and have set ourselves the challenge of walking 14.5 miles  come  rain, sleet or snow every Sunday throughout November. 

Our plan is to start with a 1 mile walk on the first weekend of November wand and finish on the last Sunday of the month with a 6.6mile walk of Bushy park. 


1/11: St James 1 mile.

8/11: Green Park, 1.2 miles.

15/11: Kensington Park, 2.7 miles.

22/11: St Hyde Park, 3 miles.

29/11 Bushy Park, 6.6 miles.

The Goal is £1400.00 and hope you can all do your bit x.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

The Wellbeing Team at Sutton Uplift are taking on the 'live below the line challenge' - this will entail living on £1 a day, for five days, for all our food and drink. We are hoping to raise a minimum of £500 for Sutton's local foodbank and raise awareness locally by providing a small insight into the hardships faced by those experiencing extreme poverty.﻿﻿﻿

As a team we regularly bond together over food, often times, quite extravagantly. Our team meetings are subsidized with fruit and coffee and we spend a lot of our time together over food, lunch or snacks.To take on this challenge is going to be a difficult one for us.

Look out on our social media across the week of the challenge, from May 8th -  12th to see updates on how we are coping, recipes and meal plans and also local or national information on poverty reduction schemes and poverty-reduction initiatives.

Title: Allsops FrancevsIreland Charity Fundraising

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Everybody is affected by the pandemic in some way or another, some more than others.

We may not be all in the same boat we are all sailing the same storm.

I am Ross Malyon currently part of Warlingham FC and the recent events I felt it was necessary as an individual and as a club to get the local community together to make a difference. 

So I am helping Caterham foodbank who are our local Foodbank and are part of the Trussell Trust network of foodbanks in the UK. www.trusselltrust.org.

In the UK, more than 14 million people are living in poverty – including 4.5 million children. We support more than 1,200 food bank centres in the UK to provide a minimum of three days’ nutritionally-balanced emergency food to people who have been referred in crisis, as well as support to help people resolve the crises they face. Between April 2019 and March 2020, food banks in our network provided a record 1.9 million food supplies to people in crisis, an 18% increase on the previous year.

We know it takes more than food to end hunger. That’s why we bring together the experiences of food banks in our network to challenge the structural economic issues that lock people in poverty, and campaign to end the need for food banks in the UK.

If you would like to help us make a difference all donations will be greatly received 🙏🏻

Description:
#NoChildHungry

This half term, Transforming Exercise & Nutrition LTD want to do our bit to help 🖤

There are many local children who will be going hungry this half term, since the Government is no longer providing vouchers for children in poverty for free school meals during school holidays...

So, our TEN coaches and many of our TEN participants will be taking part in a 450 burpee challenge from Monday 26th October - Sunday 1st November! 

That’s 1 burpee for every child registered with Colchester Food Bank!

We are doing this with the aim to try and raise £450 in total for Colchester FoodBank and to also encourage local people to donate some much needed food to the charity 💫

Did you know that a third of those in crisis that Colchester FoodBank feeds are children? 2020 has already been their busiest year ever. 

As Colchester's Bishop Roger Morris from the Diocese of Chelmsford says in his keynote speech, child poverty should already be history. No child in our nation should be starving. 

Here’s the details of Colchester FoodBank’s website, if you’d like to drop off a food parcel in place of a sponsorship:

https://colchester.foodbank.org.uk/

Finally, please do ask your MPs to help and if possible sign the petition asking the Government to support vulnerable children; #endchildfoodpoverty by implementing 3 recommendations from the National Food Strategy to expand access to Free School Meals, provide meals; activities during holidays to stop holiday hunger; increase the value of and expand the Healthy Start scheme.

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554276

Thank you everyone 🖤🚀

- Amy & The TEN Team

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For the last 3 years I have played Father Christmas at Rowans Hospice Christmas Fair which obviously didn't happen this year and I'm aware that there are far fewer opportunities for children to see Father Christmas and visit grottos in 2020 so I have decided to make recorded messages from Santa for anybody who wants one.

If you would like a video, copy and paste the following link into your browser and fill in your details on the page:
https://forms.gle/dnVvvDbV3RFaPK1X8

For each video I am asking for a small donation to Portsmouth Food Bank. No child should go hungry at Christmas or any other time of the year. From February 2019 to February 2020 Portmouth Food Bank fed 8950 people. I really dread to think how much that number has increased over the last year with everything that's been going on. I'm sure they're going to need all the help they can get.

I'm certainly not claiming I'm a brilliant Father Christmas, I have a drama degree (who hasn't??) the outfit isn't the most expensive, the setting will likely be my living room rather than a grotto and I will only have access to a basic (free) video editor so the production won't be outstanding. But it will be Father Christmas giving a personalised message to your kid(s) and will hopefully add a little bit of extra magic to Christmas for the little people.

Description:
On the night of 25th January members of 40th Greenwich Scout Troop will be sleeping outside overnight in cardboard boxes to raise money for the Greenwich Foodbank.  The Met Office is forecasting temperatures to reach -1 C and last year the Scouts woke up to find their cardboard boxes covered in snow.

They are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. G40 are proud to support this local charity.

Description:
Ay up mi duk! We're the Calverton Plough Boys.

We perform a traditional St George's mummers play on the nearest Saturday to St George's Day every year to raise funds for charity ...

... but this year, COVID restrictions still prevent us performing for live audiences.

So instead, we’re merrily live streaming our show to keep another grand local tradition going. 

Our hairy and hapless troupe of misfits will be huddled around webcams on Saturday 24 April for a one-night only live performance of the Calverton St George's Play at 8.30 pm. You can join the fun live using the link below.

Note: if you miss the live stream, the video will remain on YouTube for posterity if you want to see it later.

Event Info

  • Saturday 24 April 2021 at 8.30 pm – ST GEORGE’S PLAY LIVESTREAM link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDEPzShkMV8

Please watch and share the link to literally millions of your friends on social media. Be sure to also share our fundraising link, and donate a few quid to Arnold Food Bank, our chosen charity this year.

Visit: www.calvertonploughplay.co.uk for more info.
Title: The Calverton St George's Play (Online) 2021

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

This term all the children in year 5 took part in the Newcastle Building Society Boardroom Challenge which required us to come up with an idea for an event in support of a local charity. As a team we all decided we'd love to break a world record to support our school charity, The Gateshead Foodbank. We looked through the World Records database and found that the record for the World's Longest Food Passing Relay was yet to be broken. We thought that attempting this record would be a great way to raise awareness of and funding for the Foodbank.

To break the world record for the World’s Longest Food Passing
Relay we will need a minimum of 1000 people and 10 items of food. To achieve the record everyone must stand in a long line (like a very long snake!) and the first person in the line must pass each food item to the next person in line, and so on until all 1000 people have held each item of food. If we can achieve this we will have broken a world record!

Anyone is welcome to take part in our record attempt. However, even if you don't wish to take part you can still donate money to our cause. Wish us luck!

Description:
It is the time of year when the Church gives thanks for the harvest and here at Caldicott we normally take in food for the Slough Foodbank who then distribute it amongst those in need in the area.

Now more than ever, there is need in the community. The pandemic has resulted in an exceptional increase in the number of people finding themselves in a position whereby they are needing help.

However, our local foodbank has asked us if we could take a monetary collection this year instead as they are struggling to keep up with storage and the necessary 'quarantining' of donations. James Paget 
Chapel Master

Description:
In the last few years a December donation for our local food bank has became an office tradition. Last year each team across the office donated a (very generous) box of goods and the total amount of food took hours and numerous car trips to transport to the food bank warehouse!

This year is more challenging due to working from home and the restrictions we are all having to live with. Sadly also, the pandemic has seen a vastly increased number of people needing to use the food banks services due to COVID and the subsequent effect on jobs and the economy, with the North East continuing to be hit hard with no end yet in sight. Therefore it is really important we find a way to support them, and an online cash donation is the easiest way to do this, meaning the food bank can use this money to buy goods to give directly to their clients.

We would love to hit the £1000 mark, which works out under £5 per person across the office, so we are asking everyone to contribute £5 or whatever you can afford. Remember to add Gift aid too!

Description:
Bridgend Coronavirus Support Group’s £2 Challenge! 

We've been thinking of a way for our Bridgend Coronavirus Support Group to help people at this difficult time, without asking too much when most of us are anxious about money and the future.

Having kept in touch with the Bridgend Foodbank Charity, we think it will be really helpful to raise money for their volunteer-run base here. They make sure people across Bridgend have emergency food and basics, and rely heavily on donations which are more difficult to safely collect and accept at the moment. 

Our wonderful, supportive and positive group now has 8,000 members from across Bridgend including people who live here, work here and have loved ones here. And we thought, what if each of us donated just £2 to Bridgend Foodbank? Collectively we could raise a lot of money for them and make a huge difference to people in our community. 

Please get involved if you can :)

The Just Giving page is linked to the Bridgend Foodbank Donation page and all funds will go directly to them.

Title: Maureen Waterston 's Birthday

Description:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We should probably start at the beginning…
Back in 2000, when I was just 17, I was attacked by a group of four men. I was pretty badly beaten and woke the following day in a hospital bed with my parents by my side. The physical injuries healed, of course, but the mental scars from that night haunt me still to this day. I was afraid to leave the hospital. Then when I did go home, I was afraid to leave the house. The nightmares, flashbacks, new fear of people, fear of the dark…. It all started then.

What has this got to do with Rutland Food Bank, you ask?
Well, nothing.
But while I was once doing quite well and was going out walking everyday, I have allowed myself to become stuck in a rut again - afraid to go out apart from a few regular places that I know, when I have someone to go with me...

This morning I really wanted to go for a walk, but, I found myself "stuck". Too afraid to get in the car and go... This is crazy. I used to walk around Hambleton Peninsular almost every day, and now I find myself too scared to go... I need an incentive...

So, I have decided that I need to tell the world (well, Rutland anyway!) that I'm going for a walk, so that you can hold me to account if I don't! But more than that, I thought it would be nice if I can raise some money for those in the local community who are struggling at the moment. 

I'm going to try to walk1000miles again in 2021 having not completed the challenge during 2020 - and to start me off I would like to walk the first 5 days for the people of Rutland. I will walk around Hambleton Peninsular at Rutland water once each day and hope to raise £50 for Rutland Food Bank - any more than that would be fantastic! I myself will donate £2 per day which I will add as one payment of £10 at the end of the 5 days.

(I just want to add a little disclaimer here incase any new Covid Restrictions come into force which prevent me from walking around Hambleton Peninsular on any or all of the first 5 days of January. If this does happen I will walk as soon as any new restrictions are lifted.)

Title: Dude Walks Around

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

You may remember a few years ago, when I got involved in a mad plan to walk 12 walks of 12 miles to mark the 12 men who take their own lives every day!  As a team, we managed to raised something like £4,000 for two mental health charities: Movember and CALM. We called it "Walk This Way" - inspired by the classic collaboration between Aerosmith and Run DMC. Collaboration was at the heart of the project, and I remain fiercely proud of what we achieved together.

This time, it is a solo challenge! I've taken my inspiration from "500 Miles (I'm Gonna Be)" by The Proclaimers. Just like the song, I'm going to walk 500 miles.  All walks will be done to be COVID secure and in accordance with the latest guidance from government whether we are in lockdown or out of lockdown. The focus of my challenge this time is to raise money for the amazing Newquay Foodbank who do so much to support the most vulnerable families in this incredible community. It is especially important that these families are supported now, especially as more families have found themselves in unexpected financial hardship as a result of COVID restrictions and two national Lockdowns. 

From a personal perspective, I know what it is like to grow up in a family that was subject to financial hardship and the shadow of poverty when my dad was unemployed back in the 1980s. I remember the humiliation heaped upon me from others as I had to wear second hand clothes (not vintage or pre-loved as they are often referred to now). The memory of that was one of the defining factors that resulted in me becoming a secondary school teacher.  It makes me beyond sad to consider that there will be children in Newquay today who will experience the same or similar things to those that I experienced back when I was young.

So please support me in this challenge. Please spread the news of what I'm trying to do on social media. Please spread the stories of how Newquay Foodbank (and other equally wonderful charities and organisations) are helping those people who are most in need of our help.

And finally... will you be one of my 500 smiles?  I'm looking for at least 500 wonderful people who are willing to donate to this Just Giving page a minimum of £5.00 to support the work of Newquay Foodbank throughout this Lockdown and whatever comes after it. That would raise a lot of money to help a lot of people right here in Newquay.

Here's one final music reference for you - anybody and everybody who contributes money to this fundraiser for Newquay Foodbank would undoubtedly become one of my "Heroes"... but for more than one day.

Thank you.

Description:
A group of 15 soldiers from 3Rifles will be embarking on a charity to Cycle, Tab, run and walk the distance of 3700.5 miles in 2months, starting 06/05/20 ending 06/07/20. 

The miles is from Edinburgh to Italy, Spain, France, London and back up to Edinburgh. These are the worse affected European countries for COVID-19. 

Each member will aim to do about 246.07 miles in 2months, roughly about 4.11 miles per day. All money raised will go towards food banks. This is to cater for emergency supplies to help the thousands of people who have lost their jobs, and in dire need for basic food, and other necessities. Lets not forget the homeless, as we know that some of our veterans are also homeless and they depend heavily on food banks. 

To that end the team is humbly appealing for any amount of donation that you could contribute to go toward families and homeless people badly affected by COVID-19.

Description:
Tomorrow should have been the 11th Jam in the Castle but sadly we have had to postpone due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To say we’re disappointed is an understatement. We love hosting the event which has raised tens of thousands over the last 10 years.

But just because COVID-19 has postponed the show it doesn’t mean we still can’t enjoy the spirit of Jam.

This year we’re supporting Bridgend Food Bank. Even though we can’t all meet up in the Castle we can still have our own Jam in our Gardens and still raise money for an amazing cause.

So take a look at our page, replay the videos, look at the photos and relive Jams 1-10!

Why not send us photos or videos of your Jam in the Castle memories or if you’ve performed in the past send us a performance from home.

If you can donate a small amount to Bridgend Food Bank please do. We’ve got an army of amazing supporters who can still make a huge differed even though we can’t all be together tomorrow.

We’ll be back soon.

YOU CAN’T STOP THE JAM!

Description:
Join the auction at:

https://www.instagram.com/brahminletteringco/

Black Friday is a really tricky concept for small businesses — it’s great if you make massive profit margins or sell huge volumes (hello Amazon), but not so much for small creative businesses like mine. Plus, trampling each other for cheap TVs is sort of gross, right?

So this year I’m doing something a bit different. Starting Friday at 9am, I’ll be running my ✨MAGIC FRIDAY✨charity auction. Nab some  of my one-of-a-kind festive pieces, with 100% of profits going to Drumchapel Food Bank.

This year has been hard for us all, but it has hit lower income families even harder. Hunger has always been an issue close to my heart — how we can live in a country where some have so much, while others can’t even put basic food on the table is something that burns my wick.

So set your timers (there’s one in my Stories!) and join me 9am Friday for a bit of fun that will help those who truly need it. 

The auction will be run on:

https://www.instagram.com/brahminletteringco/
Title: Brahmin Lettering Co. Magic Friday Auction

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

During lockdown 2.0 I will be travelling around Sutton Coldfield and the surrounding areas taking Christmas doorstep portraits of you and your families. 

There is no charge from me for this service, instead I am asking for charity donations in return. All the money raised will be donated to Erdington Foodbank. This year has been extraordinarily hard for many, but hopefully together we can help some of those struggling to feed themselves and their families this winter. 

If you have had your doorstep photos taken by me, I ask that you kindly make a donation to this wonderful charity in return. The amount you donate is up to you, but please make it a minimum of £15.  

I'd like to raise as much money as possible to help this worthy cause. The Erdington Foodbank does does such amazing work within the community and benefits so many. Nobody should have to face going hungry. 

If you haven't had your photos taken but would still like to contribute, any amount is welcome and hugely appreciated, thank you. 

Thank you for getting involved and for making this such a wonderful experience, I have enjoyed every second.
